Revised on March 10, 2015

JBoss Application Server (JBoss AS) is an open-source Java EE-based application server. This class of software implements a server that runs on Java and the Java EE part of Java. Because it is Java-based, the JBoss AS operates cross-platform. You can use it on any operating system that supports Java. JBoss AS was developed by JBoss, which is now a division of Red Hat.
For more information, go to the following:
Use the EC-JBoss plugin to interact with the JBoss Application Server Version 7 (JBoss AS7) to do tasks such as managing servers and deployments.
This plugin was developed and tested with JBoss AS 7.0.1 ZAP.
Important: For all parameter descriptions in the following sections, the required parameters are in bold italics.

Plugin configurations are sets of parameters that apply across some or all of the plugin procedures. They reduce repetition of common values, create predefined sets of parameters for end users, and store credentials securely. Each configuration has a unique name that is automatically entered in designated parameters in the procedures.

ol.li: Go to Administration > Plugins to open the Plugin Manager.
Find the EC-JBoss row.
Click Configure to open the JBoss Configurations page.
Click Create Configuration.

To enable ElectricFlow to communicate with your JBoss AS, enter the following information. You may need to create additional configurations later, especially when using standalone and domain servers, because they use different port numbers.

tr.td: A unique name for the configuration with connection information for the JBoss server.
URL of the JBoss AS, including the protocol, IP address, and port number of the server, such as http://127.0.0.1:9999.

Username: The user name that ElectricFlow uses to communicate with the JBoss server.
Password: Provide the password for the Username.
Retype Password: Re-enter the password.

div.p: The JBoss Configurations page now shows the new configuration.
This procedure checks the status of a URL that corresponds to a deployment.

ol.li: Go to the CheckDeployStatus procedure.

Enter the following parameters:
Parameter Description
Server Configuration Name The name of a configuration for the JBoss server. This configuration has information about the domain that you want to start.

This procedure creates a datasource in JBoss.

ol.li: Go to the CreateDatasource procedure.

Enter the following parameters:
Parameter Description
Server Configuration Name The name of a configuration for the JBoss server.
Application Name The name of the application to deploy.
Physical Location of the JBoss Client Script Location of the JBoss command-line interface (CLI) script, such jboss-cli.bat or /path/to/jboss-cli.sh (a file or directory).
Connection Driver URL The URL for the JDBC driver connection, such as jdbc:mysql://localhost:3306/ectest.
Driver Class The fully qualifed name of the JDBC driver class, such as com.mysql.jdbc.Driver.
JNDI Name The JNDI name for the datasource that should start with java:/ or java:jboss/, such as java:jboss/datasources/MySql.
Driver Name The JDBC driver used by the datasource that can be the name of the .jar file or of the module, such as mysql-connector-java-5.1.20-bin.jar, depending on how the driver has been deployed.
Profile Name The name of the profile used in domain mode.
Datasource credential Credential that contains username and password for data source (need to be attached to step).
Enable Datasource Select this parameter to enable the datasource after it is created.

div.p: After the job runs, you can view the results on the Job Details page in ElectricFlow. In the CreateDatasource step, click the Log icon to see the diagnostic information.

The DeployApp procedure deploys the application designated by the war file path, or it enables the specified application in the deployment repository.

ol.li: Go to the DeployApp procedure.

Enter the following parameters:
Parameter Description
Server Configuration Name The name of a configuration for the JBoss server. This configuration has information about the domain that you want to start.
Physical Location of the JBoss Client Script The physical location of the JBoss client script, such as jboss-cli.bat or /path/to/jboss-cli.sh (a file or directory).
Path to the Application to Deploy The path to the application to be deployed. This parameter is required when the application does not exist in the repository.
Deployment Name The unique name of the deployment.
If the file path parameter in the Physical Location of the JBoss Client Script field is specified, the deployment name is optional. ElectricFlow uses the file name as the default value.
If the file path argument is not specified, ElectricFlow enables the existing application specified in the Deployment Name field.
Server Groups to Apply A comma-separated list of server groups to which this procedure applies.
This parameter applies only to domain servers.
You must select Server groups to apply or Apply To All Servers.
Runtime Name for Deployment The runtime name of the deployment.
Apply To All Servers Select this parameter to deploy the application to all available servers.
This parameter applies only to domain servers.
You must select Server groups to apply or Apply To All Servers.
Force Deployment Select this parameter to force the deployment application to run.
By default, if the deployment application with the specified name already exists, the deployment is aborted and a message appears.
Use Switch --force (or -f) to force the replacement of the existing deployment with the one specified in the command arguments.

The ShutdownStandaloneServer procedure shuts down a running standalone server.

ol.li: Go to the ShutdownStandaloneServer procedure.

Enter the following parameters:
Parameter Description
Server Configuration Name The name of the configuration for the JBoss server. This configuration has connection information about the standalone server. ElectricFlow uses the IP address and port number in the configuration. If this field is blank, ElectricFlow uses the default controller values (IP address and port number) to shut down the server.
Physical Location of the JBoss Client Script The physical location of the client script, such as jboss-cli.bat or /path/to/jboss-cli.sh.

div.p: After the job runs, you can view the results in the Job Details page.
In the ShutdownStandaloneServer step, click the Log icon to see the diagnostic information.
The StartDomainServer procedure starts a server in domain mode. A domain is a collection of servers.

ol.li: Go to the StartDomainServer procedure.

Enter the following parameters:
Parameter Description
Server Configuration Name The name of the configuration for the JBoss server. This configuration has information about the domain.
Physical Location of the Domain Script The absolute physical path of the domain script, such as domain.bat, /usr/tools/bin/domain.sh, or C:\Program Files\JBoss\bin\domain.bat.
Optional Configuration Name The name of the XML configuration file that ElectricFlow uses to start the domain with a different configuration.

The UndeployApp procedure undeploys the specified application and may remove application from the repository.

ol.li: Go to the UndeployApp procedure.

Enter the following parameters:
Parameter Description
Server Configuration Name The name of the configuration for the JBoss server.
Physical Location of the JBoss Client Script The physical location of the JBoss client script, such as jboss-cli.bat or /path/to/jboss-cli.sh.
Deployment Name The unique name of the application to undeploy.
Apply Undeploy to All Server Groups Select this parameter to run this procedure in all server groups in which the application is enabled.
This parameter applies only to domain servers.
You must select Server groups to apply or Apply To All Servers.
Server Groups to Apply A comma-separated list of server groups to which this procedure applies.
This parameter applies only to domain servers.
Keep Content Select this parameter to disable the deployment and keep the its content. When this is not selected, the deployment is disabled and its content is removed from the repository.

The CheckServerGroupStatus procedure gets the statuses of all servers in the specified group and compares it with the provided criteria.

ol.li: Go to the CheckServerGroupStatus procedure.

Enter the following parameters:
Parameter Description
Server Configuration Name The name of the configuration for the JBoss server.
Physical Location of the JBoss Client Script The physical location of the JBoss client script, such as jboss-cli.bat or /path/to/jboss-cli.sh.
Server group name The name of server group to be checked.
Criteria A desired status for all servers in the group.
